Review Light-assisted rechargeable zinc-air battery: Mechanism, progress, and prospects Jiangchang Chen Jinlong Luo Youlin Xiang Yingjian Yu ⁎ College of Physics Science and Technology, Kunming University, Kunming 650214, Yunnan, China College of Physics Science and Technology Kunming University Kunming Yunnan 650214 China College of Physics Science and Technology, Kunming University, Kunming 650214, Yunnan, China ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract This review provides a comprehensive introduction of light-assisted rechargeable zinc-air battery, and the influence of temperature and the evaluation parameters of the photocatalysts are discussed, emphasizing the design strategy of photocatalysts. Exploring effective energy storage systems is critical to alleviate energy scarcity. Rechargeable zinc-air batteries are promising energy storage devices. However, conventional rechargeable zinc-air battery systems face many challenges associated with electrolytes and electrodes, causing inferior electrochemistry performance. The light-assisted strategy represents a novel and innovative approach to conventional zinc-air battery technology that uses only electrical energy. This strategy effectively combines both light and electrical energy conversion/storage mechanisms. In addition, light-assisted rechargeable zinc-air batteries can achieve photocharging with or without applied electrical bias by partially using solar energy and the acceleration of oxygen reduction/evolution reaction kinetics. In this paper, the working mechanism and structural design of the light-assisted rechargeable zinc-air batteries are introduced based on the theory of photoelectrochemistry and its characteristics. Then, the latest advances in electrolyte and photocathode design strategies are discussed in detail. The performance enhancement of aqueous light-assisted rechargeable zinc-air batteries using photoelectric materials is explained. Finally, a summary and outlook on the further modification of properties of light-assisted rechargeable zinc-air batteries, especially the photovoltaic electrode catalyst design strategies, are illustrated. This review provides insights and guidance for the design of high-performance light-assisted rechargeable Zn-air batteries for next-generation energy storage devices. Keywords Zn-air battery Light-assisted Electrolyte Catalyst Semiconductor 1 Introduction With the rapid development of alternative energy sources, developing high-efficiency energy conversion and storage devices, including rechargeable metal-air batteries (RMABs), are essential [1–5]. RMABs are emerging energy storage devices, and their developments are attracting considerable attention owing to their remarkable specific energy density and environmental benignity [6–9]. These unique and favorable properties of RMABs make them potential sources of electrochemical energy [10–13]. Rechargeable zinc-air batteries (RZABs) are distinguished from numerous RMABs owing to their high theoretical energy density (1086 W h kg−1), remarkable chemical stability, simple fabrication techniques and low cost [14–16]. Compared with RZAB, conventional battery energy density depends on the quantity of active material stored in both poles [17–21]. In an RZAB, the metal reacts with the oxygen from the ambient air, resulting in an enhanced theoretical energy density [22–25]. Meanwhile, RZAB eliminates the need to store oxygen internally, which reduces the size and weight of the battery, consequently reducing the cost of production and process complexity of batteries [26–29]. Despite the promising prospective growth of RZABs, the existing battery performance is unsatisfactory due to an inferior electrochemical behavior [30–32]. Theoretically, RZABs can reversibly reduce and release O2 during the discharging and charging [33–35]. As a result, the batteries generate output voltage based on the voltage difference between the metal anode and air cathode [36–38]. However, the large overpotential caused by the sluggish dynamics of the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER) limits the application of RZABs [39,40]. The construction of a light-assisted rechargeable zinc-air battery (LARZAB) using a photo-response catalyst as the cathode is an efficient strategy recently proposed to improve the round-trip efficiency and achieve a lower charging potential, even below the discharging potential [41–44]. Solar energy is recognized as an efficacious and cost-effective alternative energy source owing to its favorable properties, such as greenness, low cost, and availability [45,46]. However, the intermittent nature of solar energy inevitably limits its extensive application. LARZABs can effectively store and directly harness solar energy, thus alleviating the drawbacks of applying solar energy [47,48]. Integrating solar energy into the RZAB system provides significant new opportunities for developing LARZABs [49,50]. Currently, a number of battery systems have introduced light-assisted strategies, including light-assisted lithium-oxygen batteries, lithium-carbon dioxide batteries, lithium-ion batteries, sodium-ion batteries, and ZABs [51–54]. However, lithium resources are relatively low in the earth’s crust and cost is always a challenge for lithium-based batteries (Fig. S1) [55]. Sodium is abundant in the earth’s crust, but its theoretical energy density is lower than that of ZABs [54]. LARZABs have inherited the advantages of ZABs of low cost, environmental friendliness, and chemical stability [56]. Therefore, the exploitation of LARZABs has become one of the emerging research hotspots [57]. In recent years, the research on LARZABs mainly focused on photocatalysts [56,58]. Significant progress has been made from developing single-function catalysts to bifunctional catalysts [41,59]. The selection of suitable photocatalysts is crucial. For instance, in 2022, Song et al. [41] developed superhydrophilic and stable bifunctional ZnO/CuO photocatalysts. Under light irradiation, a low charging potential of about 1.50 V and a high discharging potential of about 1.28 V was achieved at constant current charging and discharging. In 2023, Xue et al. [59] synthesized a stepped (S-type) TiO2-In2Se3 hollow heterojunction catalyst. Under light irradiation, the onset voltage of the ORR was 1.28 V, and the initial potential of the OER decreased to 0.48 V owing to the enhanced built-in electric field, significantly reducing the battery charging voltage. Several studies have discussed in detail the operating principle and progress of light-assisted rechargeable metal air batteries, including various open-type and closed-type light-enhanced rechargeable devices, and nanometals/metal oxides as photocatalysts, electrocatalysts, and photoelectrocatalysts [60–62]. However, little attention has been paid to the comprehensive introduction to LARZAB, including evaluation parameters, zinc anode and electrolytes, photocatalysts design strategies of LARZABs, and in situ characterization of the photocatalysts, etc. Therefore, a quick summary of progress and persisting challenges in LARZABs is imperative for future development. This article offers an overview of the latest advances and challenges in LARZABs. First, the working mechanism and the corresponding structure of LARZABs are described in detail based on the foundation of photoelectrochemistry. The research progress of zinc anode and electrolytes for RZABs is also described in detail, and the research frontier for cathode photocatalyst materials of LARZABs is elaborately elucidated. Moreover, the design strategies for photocathode catalysts in LARZABs are summarized. Finally, the challenges and underlying opportunities for viable design strategies of LARZABs as energy storage and conversion devices are proposed. By investigating and summarizing the works on LARZABs, we believe that this review could advance the development of RZABs and novel energy storage systems. 2 Working mechanisms and battery configurations To date, there are three main light-assisted strategies for improving the performance of RZABs [63] (Fig. 1 ): (1) photogenerated carrier-assisted strategies involving the use of band-structured coupled semiconductors; (2) local surface plasmon resonance (LSPR) effects by modulating the morphology and size of noble metal nanoparticles; (3) photothermal effects. The photogenerated carrier-assisted strategy is usually achieved by fabricating semiconductors with appropriate energy band structures into the photovoltaic electrodes. Researchers have used the strategy to design and fabricate a wide range of LARZABs by integrating substantial semiconductor cathode catalyst materials [41–44,50,57–59,64–70] (Fig. 2 ), in addition, different photocatalysts assembled into LARZABs exhibited excellent performance (Table S1). LSPR happens when light is incident onto nanoparticles comprising noble metals. If the incident photon frequency matches the whole vibration frequency of the conduction electrons of noble metals, the nanoparticles will show an obvious absorption effect on the photon energy. At the same time, lower energy excited electrons can produce hot electron thermalization through phonon scattering, called the local photothermal effect. The photothermal effect is a straightforward method for converting solar energy, which is present in most photocatalytic processes and also effective for most electrocatalytic procedures because the increased working temperature at the electrocatalyst interface tends to favor the thermodynamics and kinetics, thereby accelerating the reaction. Based on the physical energy band theory of solids, as exemplified by the photogenerated carrier-assisted strategy, semiconductors can be divided into a conduction band (CB) and a valence band (VB) and separated by a forbidden bandwidth (E g). In addition, the photoresponse range of a typical semiconductor photocatalyst is a crucial parameter. The E g of the semiconductor determines the critical wavelength λg of the light source. The following equation relates λ g and E g: (1) λ g = 1240 E g Moreover, UV is only 7% of the solar spectrum, where most of the wavelengths are in the visible and infrared regions (Fig. 3 a). The light absorption range directly affects photocatalytic activity. Therefore, to increase the widespread application of photocatalysts, semiconductors must have an appropriate energy band structure to absorb wavelengths in the visible range. In addition, the photocatalytic mechanism of semiconductors can be divided into the following procedures. As shown in Fig. 3(b), when the excitation energy is stronger than E g, the VB electrons in the semiconductor transit through the band gap and jump to the CB, generating equal amounts of holes and electrons in the VB and CB, respectively. The generated holes and electrons are strongly oxidized and reduced, respectively, forming a redox system. The electron and hole excited by light rapidly migrate and are trapped by oxygen (or carbon dioxide). Multiple complex oxygen reduction or evolution reactions occur on the catalyst surface. This property is ideally suited to accelerate the slow reactions of ORR and OER in RZABs. LARZABs exhibit a device structure, generally two-electrode cell systems, similar to conventional rechargeable batteries [41,50]. As shown in Fig. 3(c), LARZABs comprise a zinc anode, a membrane, an electrolyte, and an air electrode. To achieve high battery performance, the air electrode should have catalytic and gas diffusion layers. Fig. 3(d) reveals the working mechanism of LARZABs. A distinctive characteristic of LARZABs is the import of light-assisted discharging/charging processes into the battery to accelerate the slow ORR/OER at the cathode to improve overall performance. The following reactions can characterize the fundamental mechanism in the discharging and charging of LARZABs: Discharge process. (2.1) Air Cathode: photocatalyst + hv → e− + h+ (2.2) O2 + 2H2O + 4e−→4OH− (E vsRHE = 0.4 V) (2.3) Zn Anodes: Zn + 4OH−→Zn (OH)4 2−+2e− (E vsRHE = − 1.25 V) (2.4) Zn (OH)4 2− →ZnO + H2O + 2OH− (2.5) Overall reaction: 2Zn + O2 → 2ZnO (E vsRHE = 1.65 V) Charging process: (2.6) Air Cathode: photocatalyst + hv → e− + h+ (2.7) 4OH−+4h+→O2 + 2H2O (E vsRHE = − 0.4 V) (2.8) Zn Anodes: ZnO + H2O + 2OH−→Zn (OH)4 2− (2.9) Zn (OH)4 2−+2e−→Zn + 4OH− (E vsRHE = 1.25 V) (2.10) Overall reaction: 2ZnO → 2Zn + O2 (E vsRHE = − 1.65 V) Photocatalysts absorb the light with appropriate wavelengths to produce photogenerated electron-hole pairs, which can assist in the cycling processes. During the discharge process, O2 and H2O are reduced to OH− by photogenerated electrons. Zn anode is oxidized to Zn2+ and generates Zn (OH)4 2− with OH− to produce ZnO at the anode. During charging, photogenerated holes transfer to the photocathode to oxidize OH− to O2, and photoelectrons move fast to the outer circuit while Zn (OH)4 2− is reduced to Zn and OH−. Energy efficiency (η), energy savings (E s), and light-to-electric conversion efficiency (η c) are also key performance criteria in LARZABs. η can be determined by the following equation. Currently, the research on LARZABs mainly focuses on cathode catalysts [74–76]. However, the significance of zinc anode and electrolytes for LARZABs is rarely discussed. Zinc anodes and electrolytes are also essential components of LARZABs [77,78]. For instance, it is necessary to focus on the durability, dendrite formation of zinc and the high temperature stability of the zinc anode and electrolyte. Therefore, we first describe the zinc anodes and electrolytes of LARZABs in this section, and give a general discussion of maintaining zinc anode and electrolyte stability at high temperatures. Then, we elucidate the use of photocatalytic materials in the air electrode of LARZABs, and evaluation parameters of photocatalysts are also described in detail. 3.1 Zinc anode and electrolyte The zinc anode is an essential component and determines the capacity of the LARZAB in the presence of sufficient oxygen at the air cathode [79]. LARZABs are mainly fabricated with alkaline electrolytes [30]. Unfortunately, the formation of Zn dendrites is more pronounced in alkaline media than in neutral or weakly acidic media [80,81]. Uneven deposition of Zn leads to the formation of convex tips, where occurs a “tip effect”, which further attracts Zn2+ ions to be deposited on the tips, accelerating the growth of the dendrites. In addition, the alkaline ZAB charging process is accompanied by a hydrogen evolution reaction (HER), which is due to the fact that the theoretical deposition potential of Zn is significantly lower than the HER [82]. These challenges can impact the durability of zinc anodes in LARZABs. Conventional ZABs can alleviate zinc dendrites and HER by adding a modifying layer onto the zinc surface [83]. This is beneficial to increase the lifetime of the zinc anode. However, little research on this has been done in LARZABs. Furthermore, the electrolyte plays a key role in coordinating the mass transfer of the entire battery system and stabilizing the reaction intermediates [84,85]. It also determines the reaction routes and directly affects the battery performance. Long-term irradiation poses an inevitable detriment to electrolyte stability. In the absence of any cooling device, prolonged illumination significantly increases the temperature in the cell and accelerates electrolyte evaporation, thus increasing polarization and impedance [86]. Furthermore, aggressive photoelectrons/holes can directly target the electrolyte, leading to severe decomposition of electrolyte [87]. These are existing challenges for zinc anodes and electrolytes in LARZABs, especially the effect of temperature on zinc anodes and electrolytes. Unfortunately, there is few studies on zinc anodes and electrolytes in LARZABs. It might be a good strategy to harmonize the stability of the battery system by adjusting the electrolyte in LARZABs to eliminate the effect of temperature on the system. Currently, an aqueous alkaline electrolyte (KOH) with a concentration of 6 M is usually used in LARZAB systems. However, the composition of the electrolyte can also be adjusted to achieve satisfactory performance over a wide temperature range. In 2022, Zhang and Li et al. [86] developed an electrolyte for ZABs to achieve safe and efficient performance at high temperatures. The developed electrolyte (6.0 M KOH + 0.20 M Zn (Ac)2) for ZABs at elevated temperatures facilitated efficient ion diffusion. The kinetics of the positive electrochemical reaction ORR/OER was improved at high temperatures, and the negative zinc electrode exhibited anti-passivation properties at high temperatures. The competing reactions between zinc deposition and HER decreased the negative electrode Faraday efficiency during charging, which mainly limits the performance improvement of ZABs. Furthermore, the viscosity (μ) of the electrolyte decreased from 3.01 mPa s at 20 °C to 2.08 mPa s at 80 °C, indicating that the high temperature enhanced the diffusion of ions in the electrolyte to achieve a higher ionic conductivity. The electrolyte possessed an ultra-high conductivity of 997 mS cm−1 at 80 °C, which is almost twice as high as at 20 °C. In conclusion, ZAB electrolytes can withstand temperatures over 100 °C with satisfactory ionic conductivity, providing minimal internal resistance and good cell performance. This outstanding performance of the electrolyte makes ZABs a safe, high-temperature energy storage system. Therefore, many LARZAB systems currently follow this approach. Attempts to use hydrogel electrolytes instead of alkaline electrolytes also seem promising to deal with high-temperature scenarios. In 2023, Zhou et al. [88] prepared a poly (sodium acrylate) -polyvinyl alcohol (PANa–PVA)–ionic liquid (IL) hydrogel (PANa–PVA–IL) and used them to assemble flexible rechargeable ZABs (Fig. 4 a). Generally, the water concentration of hydrogel electrolytes influences the OH− transport kinetics. In addition, hydrogel electrolytes are characterized by low water absorption, weak ionic conductivity, poor water retention, and poor tolerance to high temperatures. However, PANa–PVA-IL displayed a good conductivity of 306.9 mS cm−1 and H2O absorption at normal temperature. As shown in Fig. 4(b), the ionic conductivity of PANa–PVA-IL increases with increasing temperature. Fig. 4(c) illustrates the real-time H2O retention of PVA, PANa, PANa–PVA, and PANa–PVA–IL exposed to air. The water retention of hydrogels affects ion transport kinetics, and good water retention is one of the characteristics that determine the performance of hydrogels. Fig. 4(d) shows the actual time ionic conductivity of those hydrogelsplaced in the air, demonstrating the feasibility of the hydrogel electrolytes for promotional applications. Moreover, the polarization and power density curves in Fig. 4(e) show excellent maximum power densities of 150 and 195 mW cm−2 at 25 and 60 °C, respectively. Cheng et al. [89] designed and synthesized a polarized gel electrolyte of polyacrylamide-sodium citric (PAM-SC) for flexible ZABs. The interaction between H2O and SC in the polar gel electrolyte inhibited the evaporation of water under high-temperature conditions, enabling the flexible ZAB to operate under high-temperature conditions and exhibit long-term cycle stability. Wang et al. [90] introduced a gel polymer electrolyte with a double cross-linked structure. The electrolyte was formed by polymerizing the neutralization product of acrylic acid with potassium hydroxide and acrylamide monomer under heating conditions. The assembled ZABs showed satisfactory properties over a wide temperature range and good stability and practicality under a wide range of extreme conditions. In summary, much effort has been conducted to explore electrolyte of LARZABs. However, the temperature ramp-up caused by the photothermal effect is a significant challenge for LARZABs. Therefore, the electrolyte needs to exhibit a high environmental adaptability, including the effect of temperature and humidity on LARZABs. In addition, we summarized the application of aqueous electrolytes and gel electrolytes over a wide range of temperatures, which is a key factor in determining the extensive employment of LARZABs, and aim to provide a guide in the electrolytes suitable for LARZABs. 3.2 Photocatalysts The difference between LARZABs and conventional ZABs is the introduction of photocatalyst semiconductor materials to adjust the reaction pathway, reduce the overpotential, and accelerate the cathode reaction kinetics to enhance the battery performance. However, most conventional photocatalysts have narrow light absorption, a single promotion of ORR/OER, and substantial photo-carrier recombination [57,58,68]. Moreover, a single-character photoelectric semiconductor can only facilitate the discharge or charging process. Constructing heterostructures between two or more materials is a promising approach [91]. Metal oxides and transition metal oxides such as iron oxide, tungsten trioxide, and titanium dioxide have been demonstrated with good photovoltaic properties [41,50]. Metal oxides@metal oxides, metal oxides@metal sulfides, metal oxides@other porous materials and other heterostructures have been investigated as photocatalysts [92–94]. Therefore, we will introduce in detail the progress of various photocatalysts in LARZABs in this section. Typically, photocatalysts applied to LARZABs are metal oxides or heterojunctions comprising metal oxides, metal sulfides, polymers, carbon and nitrogen compounds, and other porous materials (Fig. 5 ). 3.2.1 Metal oxides Most metal oxide materials exhibit n-type semiconductor properties due to their oxygen vacancy defect states, which can operate as electron donors. TiO2 (E g = 2.98 eV, λ g = 416 nm) is a promising photocatalyst owing to its excellent photoreactivity, suitable energy band structure, low cost, chemical stability and photocorrosion resistance [44,95]. The prolonged light illumination increases the defects of TiO2, and the generation of oxygen vacancies further promotes photogenerated carrier migration, consequently boosting its photocatalytic efficiency [96]. In 2020, Du et al. [42] reported the growth of vertically aligned TiO2 nanorod arrays with 100 nm diameter on carbon fibers. The photocathodes enhanced the performance of ZABs and effectively reduced the charging voltage from 2.4 to 0.59 V under light, which was thermodynamically impossible. This result showed that TiO2 significantly facilitated the OER process under light, which could be attributed to the photogenerated holes with strong oxidation capability in the VB of TiO2, which converted OH− to OH·, and then decomposed to release O2. Although TiO2 is considered one of the most promising photocatalysts, single-component TiO2 tends to enhance only a single process in RZABs. TiO2 compounded with other materials can overcome these drawbacks. Therefore, bifunctional catalysts are gradually becoming an attractive target for research. Xue et al. [44] designed and synthesized a TiO2@In2Se3@Ag3PO4 composite. The material had a three-layer structure, consisting of Ag3PO4 as the outer coating, In2Se3 as the middle layer, and TiO2 as the inner core. When TiO2@In2Se3@Ag3PO4 was irradiated by sunlight, the photogenerated electrons and holes migrated toward the interface of the three-layer structure. These three monomeric materials produced a synergistic effect under light irradiation. Therefore, the charge and discharge potentials of ZABs were 0.64 and 1.82 V, respectively. In2Se3 acted as a photoreceptor to boost light absorption, and the photoexcited electrons were almost gathered in the CB of In2Se3 to ameliorate the ORR and enhance the output potential during the discharge. Meanwhile, holes were mainly gathered in the VB of Ag3PO4 to accelerate the OER and to reduce the input potential during charging. In 2023, this group also synthesized a stepped (S-type) TiO2-In2Se3 hollow heterojunction catalyst and assembled into LARZAB with a single photoelectrode (Fig. 6 a and b) [59]. The onset voltage of ORR under light was 1.28 V (Fig. 6c), meanwhile, the initial voltage of OER decreased to 0.48 V (Fig. 6d). The discharge voltage of the TiO2-In2Se3 based RZAB was higher than the theoretical voltage and possessed excellent stability under illumination (Fig. 6e and f). Fig. 6(g) shows the photogenerated charge transfer in TiO2-In2Se3 following the S-scheme mechanism. Under light irradiation, photogenerated electrons at the CB of TiO2 migrated to the VB of In2Se3 because of the built-in electric field. Photogenerated electrons with high reduction ability on the CB of In2Se3 and TiO2 cooperating with highly oxidizable holes on VB of In2Se3 promoted the ORR/OER, resulting in a robust cycling stability (Fig. 6h). Furthermore, there are other similar strategies. In 2022, Song et al. [41] used an effective approach to design bifunctional ZnO/CuO composites with excellent photocatalytic activity, stability and superhydrophilicity. ZnO/CuO was homogeneously prepared on fluorine-doped tin oxide (FTO) glass substrates using the doctor blade technique. As shown in Fig. 7 (a and b), the onset voltage of ORR under illumination was 0.57 V, and the initial voltage of OER decreased to 0.9 V. The ZnO/CuO composite photoelectrode was used for the cycling of the RZAB, realizing a low charging voltage of about 1.50 V and a high discharging potential of about 1.28 V at constant current charging and discharging, respectively, under illumination conditions (Fig. 7c). The open-circuit voltage and short-circuit current were 0.9 V and 49 mA cm−2, respectively. This result was because that the valence mechanism of Cu (Cu2O/CuO) improved the performance of RZABs (Fig. 7d and e). Similar to TiO2, the iron-based oxide α-Fe2O3 (E g = 2.10 eV, absorption edge: 590 nm) also has a suitable energy band structure and excellent photoelectric stability. Hu et al. [50] introduced α-Fe2O3 thin films consisting of nanorods with an average diameter of about 70 nm, which were roughly perpendicular to the substrate. The α-Fe2O3 photocathode-based LARZABs constructed had a charging voltage of 1.64 V and a discharging voltage of 1.15 V under light (Fig. 7f). The corresponding round-trip efficiency was 70.3%. On the contrary, the efficiency in the dark was only 54.5%. In this article, another photocatalyst (BiVO4) (E g = 2.46 eV, λ g = 504 nm) was also reported. BiVO4 was composed of interconnected columnar particles. The particles had a mean particle size of about 110 nm and form a three-dimensional porous network. After the BiVO4 was illuminated, the charging voltage of the BiVO4-based ZAB achieved a low charge voltage of ∼1.30 V, an extremely small potential gap of ∼0.16 V and a very high energy efficiency of ∼87.7% at the first 3 min. Unfortunately, the discharging potential gradually decreased to ∼1.07 V and the charging potential quickly increased to ∼2.12 V after 6 h test (Fig. 7g). The observed performance degradation is due to the severe photocorrosion of BiVO4. Fig. 7(h) illustrates the sunlight-promoted charging mechanism of the α-Fe2O3 and BiVO4. The photovoltage generates when the photo-responsive electrode undergoes photoexcitation, which compensates the high charge voltage of the ZAB. 3.2.2 Metal sulfides Apart from metal oxides, metal sulfides also own a suitable energy band structure and electrochemical/photochemical stability [97]. Sarawutanukul et al. [66] introduced a photoactive bifunctional catalyst (NiCo2S4). Under irradiation, the p-type NiCo2S4 photocatalyst absorbed visible light and generated photoelectrons and holes through the photoelectric effect to directly transform light energy into electrical energy. Compared with the dark conditions, the OER and ORR overpotential under illuminated conditions were reduced by about 10% and 18.5%, respectively. In addition, the potential gap of the ZAB with NiCo2S4 as the cathode decreased from 0.82 to 0.60 V, and the round-trip efficiency increased from 59.2% to 68.8% after it was exposed to visible light. During discharge, photoelectrons were produced in the CB, while holes were generated in the VB. The highly reactive holes can further react with OH− at the liquid–solid interface, thus improving the photocatalytic process of O2. 3.2.3 Polymers Compared with metal-based semiconductors, polymer semiconductor catalysts have the advantages of simple synthesis, broad light absorption, and adjustable energy band structure, making them applicable in LARZAB. For example, catalysts prepared from photoactive polymers, such as poly(trithiophene) (pTTh), poly(1,4-di(2-thienyl)) benzene (PDTB), polyaniline nanorod arrays (PANINA), and triazine-based conjugated polymers have outstanding properties when assembled in LARZABs [42,57]. In 2019, Li et al. [57] developed pTTh polymer catalysts and used them to accelerate the ORR of LARZABs. As shown in Fig. 8 (a), the onset voltage of ORR under illumination was 1.40 V. When the pTTh photoelectrode was used for the RZAB, an ultra-high discharge voltage of 1.78 V was obtained under irradiation. The result revealed that the mechanism of the pTTh catalyst was the 2 E reaction pathway. This 2 E pathway increased discharge voltage compared with the traditional 4 E reaction pathway (thermodynamic limit of 1.65 V). In addition, during the discharge process, the p-type pTTh generated photoelectrons, which reduced O2 to intermediate HO2 − and then was disproportionate to OH− (Fig. 8b). Moreover, the group further reported LARZABs with PDTB polymers as substrates [42], as shown in Fig. 8(c), the battery system consists of two photoelectrodes. During discharge, the PDTB cathode undergoes ORR and forms a circuit with the zinc anode. In a reverse process, the TiO2 cathode then conducts OER, releasing oxygen into air (Fig. 8d). The onset voltage of ORR under illumination was 1.44 V (Fig. 8e). The useful contribution of PDTB to the discharging process of ZABs was demonstrated, during the discharge process, photoelectrons from the CB of PDTB were donated to O2 and reduced to O2 .- that then transformed to OH− (Fig. 8f). Moreover, the discharge potential of 1.90 V was obtained by assembling PDTB onto the ZABs (Fig. 8g). 3.2.4 Carbon and nitrogen compounds Generally, most metal oxide and sulfide photocatalysts possess an E g greater than 3 eV, which makes them absorb only UV light. However, ultraviolet light makes up only 7% of the sunlight. Developing photocatalysts with visible light responsiveness is essential. In particular, metal-free polymeric carbon nitride family (CXNY) photocatalysts have captured considerable attention because of their adjustable structures, simple synthesis, and extensive range of applications [98]. For instance, C3N4 and C4N gain significant attention owing to their unique electronic structures, excellent chemical stability, and practical applicability in electrocatalysis, photocatalysis, and energy storage [99,100]. In 2022, Yu et al. [64] constructed an S-scheme heterojunction array with n-type C4N and n-type TiO2 nanorods (C4N@TiO2NR) to assemble a LARZAB. As shown in Fig. 9 (a), the C4N modification had almost no impact on the rutile phase structure and nanoarray morphology of TiO2NR, which was assembled into light-assisted acid-base asymmetric air battery (LABAB) and light-assisted acid-base battery (LAB). During charging and discharging under illumination, a record of 0.43 V/2.02 V at 0.1 mA cm−2 and 0.87 V/1.86 V at 10 mA cm−2 was obtained due to the additional compensation of light energy (Fig. 9b). Fig. 9(c) demonstrates the superior OER polarization curve of C4N@TiO2NR, and the polarization of C4N@TiO2NR was dramatically reduced under illumination. The S-scheme heterojunction attributed to the appropriate Fermi energy level and energy band structure, leading to a strong built-in electric field, which provided a high redox capability of photogenerated electron-hole pairs to suppress the complexation (Fig. 9d). Meanwhile, Wang et al. [68] successfully synthesized Ni12P5@NCNT through one-step pyrolysis of dicyandiamide, iron (III) phosphate, and nickel (II) chloride at 90 °C and a heating rate of 2 °C min−1. The intensely coupled P-type Ni12P5 and N-type NCNT form multiple p-N junctions. SEM shows a randomly entangled Ni12P5@NCNT segment. Linear scanning voltammetry revealed that Ni12P5@NCNT used as a photocathode in LARZABs improved both ORR/OER potentials under illumination (Fig. 9e and f). The Ni12P5@NCNT composite photoelectrode was used for the RZAB, achieving an excellent cyclic performance at constant current charging and discharging, respectively (Fig. 9g). The group also coupled photoactive poly(3,4-ethylene-dioxythiophene)-block poly (ethylene oxide) with MWCNTs (PEDOT-PEO@MWCNT) as light-assisted bifunctional photocathodes to assemble LARZABs [65]. The charge and discharge currents under UV irradiation increased by 10.0% and 9.0%, respectively. 3.2.5 Porous materials Generally, photogenerated carrier separation is crucial in photocatalysis. In the past decade, porous materials, such as metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) and covalent organic frameworks (COFs), have been extensively studied in gas adsorption and separation, multiphase catalysis, photovoltaics, and wastewater treatment [101–103]. MOFs and COFs possess excellent photogenerated charge separation properties [104–106]. However, they have not been extensively studied in LARZABs. Here, we introduce the excellent photovoltaic properties of MOFs and COFs, which are believed to be gradually applied in LARZABs. In 2023, Lu et al. [107] reported a solid microporous Zn-MOF (JNU-204) containing benzothiadiazole units known for photon absorption efficiency (Fig. 10 a). The UV–vis diffuse reflectance spectra (UV–vis DRS) revealed that the absorption spectrum of JNU-204 was in the visible range (Fig. 10b). Using the Tauc plot method, the E g of JNU-204 was determined to be around 2.35 eV. Additionally, the flat-band potential (Fig. 10c) of JNU-204 was estimated to be −0.897 eV (versus Ag/AgCl) at pH 6.8. Furthermore, the LUMO voltage (Fig. 10d) was appraised to be −0.897 eV, and the HOMO voltage was further estimated to be 1.453 eV. The result shows that the introduction of benzothiadiazole to the MOF enhances the photogenerated charge separation, and the photocatalyst performance can also be promoted by suppressing photogenerated carrier recombination. Cai et al. [108] synthesized Ru/MOF/C3N4 catalysts in situ by loading Ru single atoms into MOF. The photoluminescence emission spectra revealed that the Ru/MOF/C3N4 photocatalyst exhibited fluorescent light at 470 nm. The transient fluorescence spectra (PL) show that the average PL lifespan of Ru/MOF/C3N4, MOF/C3N4, and MOF are 35.8, 28.1, and 3.3 ns, respectively. Ru single atoms increase the energy level in the MOF band gap and the concentration of photogenerated carriers. Moreover, COFs can exhibit efficient charge separation and low exciton binding energy. Zhou et al. [109] constructed a series of classical molecular polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (anthracene, pyrene, and perylene) connected with olefins as type II heterostructure COFs (named TMBen). In particular, the perylene-modified COFs exhibited excellent photocatalytic reduction properties and were capable of spontaneous charge ionization driven by light, accelerating the charge separation and transfer under illumination. Thus, the catalytic performance of the modified COFs significantly improved. In this section, we introduced and discussed recent reports based on photocatalysts for LARZABs from five aspects. Metal oxide-based photocatalysts are the most widely reported type among them. Generally, metal oxides are characterized by a relatively large E g, which is expected to be overcome by compositing with other materials to form a bifunctional catalyst. Meanwhile, the light-assisted strategy ensures its promising prospect in the field of energy storage and broadens its application scope. Other types of photocatalysts are less reported than metal oxides photocatalysts in the research of LARZABs, but they can also exhibit excellent performance. Therefore, much effort should be made to develop novel types of photocatalysts suitable for LARZABs in the future. Besides, we briefly introduced the battery structure with two-electrode and three-electrode system. The two-electrode system is the most reported type and assembling bifunctional catalysts in a single photoelectrode can avoid the issues of complicated fabrication processes and fulfill the advantage of portability. The three-electrode system shows great performance but it is still unsatisfactory regarding the space occupation, which limits its further application. 3.3 Evaluation parameters of photocatalysts In the field of LARZABs, some important evaluation parameters are needed to qualitatively assess the photocatalytic activity. Here, we introduce the concepts or definitions of some basic parameters different from those of conventional ZABs for easier understanding. I-t curve can be used to measure the magnitude of photocatalyst photocurrent. Mott Schottky reflects the flat band potential of the photocatalyst and determines whether the photocatalyst is a p or n-type semiconductor. UV–vis DRS exhibits the light absorption wavelength of the photocatalyst, and the corresponding band gap can be determined from the Tauc’s plots by (αhν) 1/n = A(hν-E g), where E g, A, ν, and α represent the energy band gap, constant, light frequency and light absorption value, respectively, and n depends on whether the photocatalyst is indirect (n = 2) or direct (n = 1/2) semiconductor. In addition, the energy band structure of the photocatalyst can be obtained by combining the Mott Schottky. Photoluminescence spectrum (PL) evaluates the recombination degree of electron-hole pair of the photocatalyst. Surface photovoltage (SPV) measures the voltage change on the semiconductor surface after exposure to light. In addition, the photocurrent density is the ratio of the photocurrent generated on the photoelectrode to its light area under solar irradiation, and can be expressed as J p = J m a x × η a b s × η s e p × η i n j , where J p represents the actual measured photocurrent density, J max is the maximum theoretical photocurrent density of the semiconductor photoelectrode, η abs is the photo-absorption efficiency of the photoelectrode, η sep is the charge separation efficiency of the photoelectrode, and η inj represents the surface charge injection efficiency of the photoelectrode. Incident monochromatic photon-electron conversion efficiency (IPCE) is defined as the ratio of the number of electrons flowing through the closed circuit to the number of photoelectrons in the incident monochromatic light, and it is used to evaluate the photoelectric conversion efficiency at different wavelengths. IPCE is formulated as I P C E = | J p - J d | × 1240 λ × P i n , where J p is photocurrent density, J d is current density in dark conditions, λ is the incident monochromatic light wavelength, and P in is the optical power density to which the photoelectric electrode is subjected. According to the photoelectric conversion efficiency formula, a high IPCE means a higher J p under the same circumstances, and the contribution of light energy to the total energy is enhanced under low or high current densities. On the contrary, a low IPCE means that the J p is smaller under the same circumstances, and the proportions of photocurrent density to total current density and light energy to total energy decrease. At high current densities, the photocurrent density appears negligible compared with the large current density. Therefore, it is crucial to improve the IPCE of photocatalysts in LARZABs. In summary, we introduced the commonly used methods for evaluating the performance of photocatalysts. Moreover, photocatalysis is a rather complex process involving multiple electron/hole transfers and multiple spatiotemporal scales. Some conventional characterizations (e.g., steady-state photoluminescence, photoresponse currents, time-resolved photoluminescence, etc.) can characterize the separation/transfer and recombination of photogenerated charges at the ensemble level. However, the direct observation of separation and migration direction of photogenerated charges on the photocatalysts remains a significant challenge. Therefore, apart from electrochemical tests, it is necessary to complement many advanced in situ characterization techniques. Introducing light fields in the in-situ technique is more demanding on the device. Currently, scanning probe microscopy (SPM) has been successfully used to explore the separation and distribution of photoexcited charges and active sites of photocatalyst particles surface at the nanometer scale, especially for Kelvin probe force microscopy (KPFM) [110]. Synchronous illumination X-Ray photoelectron spectroscopy (SI-XPS) has been extensively used in the field of studying charge migration in photocatalytic materials [111]. These will be of great help in understanding the photocatalyst mechanism. Therefore, the development of in situ technologies is very necessary. 4 Design strategies for photocathode catalysts At present, the research on LARZABs is predominantly focused on photocatalysts. The photocatalysts are irradiated with sunlight to separate the electron-hole pairs, and the photogenerated carriers enhance the electrochemical performance of the RZABs. However, the separated electron-hole pairs compound on a large scale and are accompanied by luminescence and heat with a compounding rate close to 90% [112]. Substantial electron-hole pairs are also consumed during transfer or captured by defects [113]. Therefore, design strategies for catalysts of LARZABs are mainly concentrated on enhancing electron-hole pair separation and migration, expanding active surface area and broadening light absorption wavelengths, and other auxiliary approaches are presented in Fig. 11 . 4.1 Enhancing electron-hole pair separation and migration The concentration of photogenerated electron-hole pairs is one of the pivotal factors that determines the performance of photocatalysts. Thus, carrier separation and transfer play vital roles in photoelectrochemical processes. Many strategies, including heterojunction, Stokes junctions, defect engineering, and crystalline interface engineering, have been introduced to separate and migrate the photogenerated carriers. 4.1.1 Heterojunction Heterojunction is the interface between semiconductors with different energy band structures. Currently, type II, p-n, direct Z-type, and S-type heterojunctions can effectively strengthen the separation of electron-hole pairs, leading to effective suppression of recombination and enhancement of the redox capability of photogenerated carriers (Fig. 12 ), which are beneficial for LARZABs [41,59,114–116]. The VB and CB energy levels of semiconductor A are more positive than those of semiconductor B in the type II heterojunctions (Fig. 12a). Under light illumination, the photogenerated electrons are transferred from CB of semiconductor A to VB of semiconductor B, and the photogenerated holes are reversed, which induces effective carrier separation and thus enhances the photocatalytic performance. The p-n heterojunction has an energy band structure similar to that of the type II heterojunction, the difference is that the p-n heterojunction generates an internal electric field (IEF) at the interface between the n-type and p-type semiconductors in the absence of an external bias (Fig. 12b), which can promote photogenerated carrier separation. Direct Z-type heterojunctions are widely used due to their efficient separation of photocarriers and strong redox capability. In the direct Z-type heterojunction scheme, holes in VB of semiconductor A and electrons in CB of semiconductor B can be combined without an electron mediator (Fig. 12c). The charge transfer mechanism of S-type heterojunctions combines Z-type and type II heterojunctions. However, the S-type heterojunctions can retain the effective photogenerated carriers and recombine meaningless electrons and holes (Fig. 12d). 4.1.2 Stokes junctions Light absorption and separation of photogenerated electron-hole pairs can be optimized by combining semiconductors with metals, such as Pt, Ag, and Au, to form Schottky junctions. When the work function of the semiconductor is lower than that of the metal, more electrons tend to transfer from the semiconductor to the metal, forming a Schottky barrier, which acts as an energy obstacle to prevent photoelectron and hole bonding. 4.1.3 Defect engineering The defects introduced into semiconductors capture carriers and prevent photoelectron-hole pair recombination because electrons or holes are easily captured by defects. Metal oxides, such as TiO2, α-Fe2O3, and BiVO4, can increase oxygen vacancies under prolonged light exposure, thus improving electron/ion mobility and catalytic activity [117]. In addition, nitrogen vacancies can also enhance carrier separation [51]. 4.1.4 Crystalline interface engineering Various arrangements of atoms on different crystalline surfaces of the same catalyst material endow semiconductor materials with special surface electronic structures, built-in electric fields, redox active sites, molecular adsorption, and photocatalytic activity. The crystalline interface engineering technology can effectively enhance carrier separation and transfer. However, its application in LARZABs is rarely studied. For instance, the (110) crystalline surface engineering of Fe2O3 enhances the adsorption capacity and photocatalytic activity of oxygen intermediates [118]. In addition, it enables the prompt generation of photoelectrons and the simultaneous formation of a uniform photoelectric field across the electrode in visible light, accelerating O2 diffusion and electron transfer, thus preventing premature battery breakdown. 4.2 Enlarging active surfaces In LARZABs, the active sites on the surface of the photocatalysts directly affect the photon absorption, carrier generation and subsequent photoelectrochemical reactions. According to the η c = E A A 1 P i n t A 2 , the catalyst surface area A 1 is related to the η c, when the surface area especially the active area is larger under the same circumstances, the higher η c will be obtained. Conventional photocatalysts have insufficient exposed active sites due to the limited surface area. Therefore, constructing various nanostructures (e.g., nanowires, nanorods, and nanotube arrays) on the surface of the photocatalysts can expand the surface area and enhance active sites, which in turn enhances the absorption of light. Meanwhile, porous materials are gradually gaining considerable attention in LARZABs owing to their numerous active sites, which can be exposed to efficiently adsorb O2 molecules. 4.3 Broadening light absorption wavelength Most energy in sunlight is concentrated in the visible range. As shown in Fig. 2(a), the proportion of ultraviolet light in the solar spectrum is only 7%, and most solar spectrum wavelengths are visible and infrared. The light absorption range is an essential factor directly affecting the photocatalytic activity; thus, suitable photocatalytic materials should be selected. Therefore, constructing suitable energy band structures or incorporating dye-sensitized molecules and other molecules with strong light absorption is an effective strategy. 4.3.1 Band structure engineering Having an energy band structure is an essential feature of semiconductors and the p-type and n-type semiconductors are the most widely studied semiconductors. When a semiconductor is in contact with a liquid, a space charge region is established, and the semiconductor energy band is bent. Fermi energy level in solid state physics means the highest energy level occupied by electrons at 0 K, which marks the electron filling level. The Fermi energy levels of p-type and n-type semiconductors are close to the VB and CB edges, respectively. As shown in Fig. 11, for n-type semiconductors, the Fermi energy level tends to be harmonized after the electrode is in touch with the liquid, making VB and CB bend upward together. The substantial electron will accumulate in the surface layer of the semiconductor. However, the energy band of p-type semiconductors is tilted downward, and substantial holes accumulate on the surface of the semiconductor. For instance, the n-type semiconductor TiO2 (E g = ∼3.0 eV) with a narrow bandgap has a strong light-absorbing ability [42]. The polymer semiconductor pTTh (E g = 1.97 eV) can absorb light up to 630 nm [57]. WO3 (E g = ∼2.5–2.8 eV) also has a wide range of visible light response and good electron mobility [119]. Furthermore, α-Fe2O3 (E g = 2.10 eV) has a suitable energy band structure and excellent photoelectric stability, and the absorbed light wavelength is 590 nm [50]. 4.3.2 Dye sensitization Dye sensitization operates on the principle that uses dye molecules adsorbed on the semiconductor surface to trap visible light. Photogenerated carriers are stimulated in the dye molecules and injected into the semiconductor energy levels. The stimulated dye molecules can be restored to their original state by reacting them with redox mediators. For instance, I3 − is widely used redox intermediates that can be converted to 3I− in the presence of light [120]. Thus, the photovoltaic properties of the material are enhanced. Apart from using conventional dye agents, phthalocyanines can also be used as photosensitizers in the cells. The introduction of phthalocyanine compounds into the catalyst significantly increases light absorption capacity [52]. 4.4 Other auxiliary approaches During the photoelectrode reaction process, substantial bubbles will inevitably appear on the catalyst surface, preventing the further progress of the photoelectrode reaction. Applying a magnetic field can probably solve this problem. Additionally, the catalyst surface undergoes prolonged light exposure. Thus, the light and heat fields should also be taken into consideration. 4.4.1 Light and magnetic fields The recombination of photogenerated carriers hampers the lifetime of photocatalysts. Generally, magnetic field can modulate electrochemical reactions. Magnetic field in solar cells has shown efficient separation of carriers. Therefore, the combined action of light and magnetic fields can be used as an innovative strategy to enhance carrier separation. This is due to the fact that the Lorentz force can drive the direction the movement of photogenerated electrons and holes to achieve enhanced charge separation [121]. A magnetic field that is used as an effective technique for migrating energy across physical space can enhance the electrocatalytic capability by facilitating mass transfer and accelerating charge transfer. 4.4.2 Light and heat fields The photothermal effect accompanies the process of photoelectrocatalysis. Under prolonged light illumination, the temperature increases, thus the light and heat fields are closely linked. Photothermal catalysis is an innovative technology that combines photochemical and thermal catalytic processes, which can effectively utilize full-spectrum sunlight to catalysis various chemical reactions [122]. In addition, the LSPR of noble metals induced plasmonic thermal and hot electron effects also can simultaneously accelerate ORR and OER, reduce the reaction activation energy and enhance the selectivity of discharge product to mitigate unfavourable side reactions. For example, silver has an excellent LSPR effect, which induces the formation of vibrationally excited state of reactants (O2) on the ground-state potential energy surface, thereby reducing the reaction barrier of ORR and OER [51]. In summary, the difference between LARZABs and conventional ZABs is the introduction of photocatalyst semiconductor materials, which are essential for LARZABs. Here, we summarize the main design strategies for LARZABs. The heterojunction strategy is the most extensively applied strategy, and other strategies are also very important in LARZABs. Notably, the combination of light and thermal field or magnetic field is a promising strategy. 5 Summary and outlook In this review, we summarize the fundamentals of LARZABs based on the operating principles of photoelectrochemistry, and describe the existing challenges of LARZABs. Meanwhile, we give a general discussion of maintaining stability of zinc anode and electrolyte at high temperatures. Recent advances and a general classification of photocatalyst materials in LARZABs are also discussed. Evaluation parameters of photocatalysts are further described in detail. Then, the design strategies for photocathode catalysts in LARZABs are elucidated. The light-assisted strategy can effectively be used to prepare RZABs with the expectation of enhanced electrochemical performance. Moreover, in some cases, the performance of light-assisted RZABs exceeds the theoretical input/output limits of traditional RZAB systems, demonstrating that RZABs can be applied in wide temperature ranges and different atmospheres, and providing insights and guidance for the design of high-performance LARZABs for next-generation novel energy storage devices. Although LARZABs have achieved significant progress in recent years, many existing challenges still need to be addressed in terms of the working mechanism, stability, and applications. (1) Currently, LARZABs are still in the infancy stage; as a result, the working mechanism is unclear. First, LARZABs involve multistep photoelectrochemical and electrochemical processes during the discharge/charge process, which becomes more complex with prolonged light exposure. This process requires a comprehensive understanding of the fundamentals of photoelectrochemistry and electrochemistry. Meanwhile, it also poses a significant challenge to detection tools and theoretical calculations. Then, the rate-determining steps in the cathodic reaction of LARZABs are not comprehensively understood to know if they belong to electrochemical or photoelectrochemical reaction regulation or both. Most conventional photocatalysts have narrow light absorption, a single promotion of ORR/OER, and limited photo-carrier recombination. Therefore, it is crucial to rationalize the design of photocathodes that exhibit bifunctional catalysts, wide light absorption, and rapid photo-carrier transfer in future studies. In addition, the issue of thermodynamics in LARZABs should also be of concern. Since the LARZAB system operates under prolonged light exposure, the system temperature will inevitably increase, which will lead to a change in the Gibbs free energy. Photocatalysts may be degraded and cause destabilizing ORR and OER at high temperatures, and the electrolyte faces severe volatilization, and the parasitic hydrogen precipitation reactions are enhanced at high temperatures, leading to a decrease in anode Faraday efficiency. Therefore, the following issues may need to be carefully considered in future studies: (i) the thermodynamic reversibility of the light-assisted discharge and charging processes, and (ii) the effect of light on the thermodynamics/kinetics and the long-term stability of the RZABs. Therefore, a comprehensive understanding of the working mechanism is required to rationally design stable LARZABs. (2) Improving the stability and the cycle life of electrolytes under light is also one of the critical factors. Therefore, apart from aqueous electrolytes, other electrolytes, including solid-state and gel electrolytes, can also be applied. In addition, additives can also be added to the electrolyte to alleviate the influence of high temperatures on the electrolyte. For example, organophosphate flame retardant additives can improve the thermal stability of the electrolyte, thereby reducing the risk of thermal runaway in the battery [123]. Notably, ZABs face severe challenges under extreme low temperatures, especially with aqueous electrolyte systems, which can face electrolyte freezing and catalyst performance degradation. Fortunately, since LARZABs operate under prolonged light exposure, they might be able to be applied at extreme low temperatures because of the presence of photothermal effects. Photothermal effect prevents electrolyte and catalyst from failing at extreme low temperatures. Therefore, LARZAB is expected to make breakthroughs in low-temperature environments in the future. (3) Material cost and manufacturing process issues should be mitigated when constructing LARZABs. Two separate photocathodes can be used in a LARZAB, but it would lead to complex configurations and operations. Combining a bifunctional catalyst on a single photocathode can reduce material costs and complex manufacturing processes. Future research should be devoted to more practical LARZABs. However, most of the research on LARZABs conducted under diverse experimental circumstances requires substantial efforts to achieve practical performance requirements. Most LARZABs can only exhibit superior performance under light conditions and inferior performance under dark conditions. Thus, future LARZABs should be designed to tolerate natural light or even full solar wavelengths, which will simultaneously require photocathodes with excellent photocatalytic and electrocatalytic activities. Large-scale applications of LARZABs will require a compact device with favorable light and air permeability. Furthermore, future batteries should also be safe, lightweight, flexible, and inexpensive to meet the growing wearable requirements. In conclusion, recent works have made outstanding achievements; however, LARZABs are still in the infancy stage. LARZABs have higher requirements in terms of device transmittance than RZABs, but the advantages of LARZABs in energy, power densities, and application ranges make them one of the most promising novel types of energy storage devices. Therefore, much efforts should be invested in the study of LARZABs. We hope that this review will provide guidance and promote the future development. Jiangchang Chen is a master student majoring in condensed matter physics in Kunming University. His research interests include metal-organic framework and air batteries. Yingjian Yu received his Ph.D. degree in Xiamen University in 2017 and worked in Kunming University. His current research interests include metal ion batteries, air batteries, and photocatalysis.

coredata.dc:description: Exploring effective energy storage systems is critical to alleviate energy scarcity. Rechargeable zinc-air batteries are promising energy storage devices. However, conventional rechargeable zinc-air battery systems face many challenges associated with electrolytes and electrodes, causing inferior electrochemistry performance. The light-assisted strategy represents a novel and innovative approach to conventional zinc-air battery technology that uses only electrical energy. This strategy effectively combines both light and electrical energy conversion/storage mechanisms. In addition, light-assisted rechargeable zinc-air batteries can achieve photocharging with or without applied electrical bias by partially using solar energy and the acceleration of oxygen reduction/evolution reaction kinetics. In this paper, the working mechanism and structural design of the light-assisted rechargeable zinc-air batteries are introduced based on the theory of photoelectrochemistry and its characteristics. Then, the latest advances in electrolyte and photocathode design strategies are discussed in detail. The performance enhancement of aqueous light-assisted rechargeable zinc-air batteries using photoelectric materials is explained. Finally, a summary and outlook on the further modification of properties of light-assisted rechargeable zinc-air batteries, especially the photovoltaic electrode catalyst design strategies, are illustrated. This review provides insights and guidance for the design of high-performance light-assisted rechargeable Zn-air batteries for next-generation energy storage devices.
